intro: Galium syriacum, commonly known as Syrian bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to regions of the Mediterranean and Middle East. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems that often root at the nodes. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, simple, and often have a slightly hairy texture. Galium syriacum is often found in moist, shaded environments such as woodland edges and stream banks.
